items.title: Canada Post says layoffs aim to ‘align our management team' amid overhaul
items.description: The company said the changes 'will align with the government’s expectation that leadership and structural change from within the Corporation is essential.'

items.title: Interior Health deals with 2 waves of resignations, BC Conservatives call for action
items.description: Health Minister Josie Osborne said the province is focused on supporting doctors and other health care professionals during a time of mounting pressure.

items.title: First Nation and Canada begin legal battle over ‘grossly underfunded’ on-reserve schools
items.description: The Canadian Human Rights Tribunal has begun hearing a potentially precedent-setting legal battle between Canada and the Mississaugas of the Credit First Nation about the alleged systemic underfunding of on-reserve schooling in Ontario.

items.title: Drug to slow early-stage Alzheimer's disease approved by Health Canada
items.description: Lecanemab is the first medication approved in Canada that targets the buildup of amyloid plaque in the brain, which is believed to be an underlying cause of Alzheimer's disease.

items.title: People who lived at Ontario Training Schools seek closure 8 years after start of class action alleging abuse
items.description: People who lived at Ontario Training Schools are suing the province, alleging abuse was rampant at the children's detention centres. Nearly eight years after a class action was launched, the case is still stuck in the civil system. Lawyers say it’s another casualty of underfunded courts.

items.title: Governments Of Canada and Manitoba Strengthening Justice for Canada's First Responders
Canadian studies set to be conducted on ISS. What to know
items.description: The studies will examine such things as astronauts' mental health and how their bodies adapt to microgravity and cope with space anemia.

items.title: As tastes change, Alberta’s craft brewers expand their offerings
items.description: According to Statistics Canada, beer consumption in Alberta has declined over the past decade. During the same time period, the market share of ciders, coolers and ready-to-drink cocktails has doubled.

items.title: The Bank of Canada could cut rates again. It likely won't help food prices
items.description: As many Canadians struggle with affording essentials like food, experts say an interest rate cut by the Bank of Canada could help consumers, but not as much for grocery prices.

items.title: Ford government to limit debate, skip public hearings on bill to scrap speed cameras
items.description: Ontario Premier Doug Ford's government is proposing to limit debate and avoid public input on three pieces of legislation, including one that would end the province's speed camera program.

items.title: How Canadian charities fund illegal West Bank settlements
items.description: An investigation from CBC's the fifth estate follows the trail of millions of dollars in tax-deductible donations sent through Canadian charities to support Israeli settlements deemed illegal under international law.

items.title: As Carney set for key China talks, Poilievre urges ‘results' on tariffs
items.description: Conservative Leader Pierre Poilievre said Canadians expect Prime Minister Mark Carney to get some results from his upcoming meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping.

items.title: Manitoba Government Expands Care for Dialysis Patients and Mothers in Norway House Cree Nation
Could ‘Plan México’ be the guide for ‘Plan Canada’
How Certified Canadian Publishers Keep Our Stories Close to Home
items.description: A new national program helps readers easily spot and support Canadian-owned book publishers.

items.title: Carney mum on whether he saw Ontario's anti-tariff ad beforehand
‘Forever Canadian' petition surpasses goal, collects 456K signatures
items.description: The final tally is far greater than the required 294,000 signatures to initiate a possible referendum in Alberta.

items.title: Return to office for Ontario civil servants 'unnecessarily confusing,' unions say
items.description: The return to office last week by thousands of Ontario public servants has been "disrespectful,”  “piecemeal” and filled with “unnecessary confusion,” say the workers' unions, who point out some ministries and agencies still don't have enough space to meet Premier Doug Ford’s order.

items.title: BC’s Government Employee Strike Is Over. Here’s What Comes Next
items.description: The tentative deal clears the way for other public sector unions to fight for better wages.

items.title: N.B. business in trademark tangle with Alberta government over licence plates
Say cheese? Why you'll soon have to take photos when entering, exiting U.S.
items.description: Travellers will soon be required to have their photograph taken when entering or leaving the U.S. by air, sea or land — including Canadians and even American citizens.

items.title: B.C. sees 1st avian flu outbreaks since January as 9 confirmed in poultry stocks
items.description: A list published by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency shows the virus has been detected in nine commercial poultry flocks in the region over the last two weeks.

items.title: The Beaches make a play for Canadian rock royalty at Doug Mitchell
items.description: The Beaches are making more than just waves.

items.title: Vancouver May Get a Major New City Plan. It’s Not Enough
items.description: Council will vote on an approach that assumes just building more will spur affordability, even though that’s not true.

items.title: BC Residents May Have to Cover a Property Tax Break for Pipelines
items.description: After lobbying, BC Assessment slashed its appraisals of the industry’s infrastructure.

items.title: Which industry in each province is most threatened by tariffs?
items.description: As tariffs make an impact, Canadian industries are finding themselves competing for priority in trade negotiations. Here are the industries under threat in each province.

items.title: More Alberta parents pushing back against vitamin K injection for newborns, some doctors say
items.description: Some Alberta doctors say they're seeing a recent and concerning trend of new parents either questioning or refusing vitamin K injections, which have been given to newborns as standard practice for decades.

items.title: 86-year-old man with Alzheimer's walks out of Saskatoon care home undetected, dies days later
Halloween costumes don't have to come from a store. Here are some tricks to make your own
items.description: Some people are trading in store-bought Halloween costumes for do-it-yourself options. Hot glue, dollar-store materials and items that can be found at home are all you need to create affordable, high-quality get-ups.

items.title: AI 'hallucinations' could prove real problem for owner of fire-ravaged Vancouver property
items.description: As the owner of a fire-ravaged Vancouver property he's been accused of neglecting, Fu De Ren has defended himself in civil proceedings and bylaw trials. But his inclusion of alleged AI "hallucinations" as part of a self-represented bid to cut his property's assessed value in half may end up costing him money.

items.title: Arctic fossil is northern-most rhino species ever found
items.description: Millions of years ago, a pony-sized, hornless rhino wandered through the woods and munched on leaves in what is now northern Nunavut. A new study identities it as a new species, and offers an intriguing explanation for how it got there.

items.title: Calgary recount confirms Jeromy Farkas elected as mayor
items.description: On Tuesday, Elections Calgary released updated numbers, which show that Jeromy Farkas won the election with 91,112 votes to Sharp's 90,496, a difference of 616 votes.
